text:
Bailey is at the Small
Business Administration. She's the associate director
or associate administrator,

and also is the
head of the office of investment innovation--
innovation and investment.

And we can unpack more
about what that means but by and large,
it means that Bailey helps lead the deployment
of billions of dollars

throughout the US
innovation ecosystem. Again, something
we'll talk more about. Some programs are the SBIC,
small business Investment

Corporation, Small Business
Innovation Research, Small Business Technology
Transfer, the Growth Accelerator

Fund competition, Federal and
State Technology Partnership Program. And Bailey also comes from a
really interesting background

in the capital markets, which
we can talk about, especially most recently at T Rowe Price.

Bailey, you can also help me
with some of those acronyms that I got wrong along the way.

Bailey and I had the chance to
work together in government. And she is one of the best
public servants that I met

and one of the most forward
leaning, and one of the people who's made the most impact
in the last several years.

It was a real honor
to serve with Bailey, and a real honor to
have her here on campus.

Let's give her round of
applause to welcome her here. [APPLAUSE]

So, Bailey, let's actually
start with your journey into government. Yes. It definitely is not
linear, although it's

been an absolute privilege
to be in government. I have to say I wake
up excited every day, even though I'm
frustrated some days,

but would like things
to move faster, it's an absolute privilege. And I do recommend to
anyone, if you ever

think about giving
back and serving

either in a federal
position or state or even in your
local government,

it's amazing what you can do. And we need talented,
mission-driven individuals

serving our country
in all capacities. But it definitely
was not linear. I came out of college and ended
up in management and strategy

consulting. And then when they asked
me which practice area I wanted to be in, I
said, financial services,

because that is the business
that my father had been in

and my grandfather. They had been at the
Chicago Mercantile Exchange and board of trade.

And then my father had
had basically, I guess, you'd call it a fintech in the
'70s and '80s a few times over.

And so I was like, OK,
no financial services. And it turned out that we were
launching a research practice

for buy side asset
management firms to help them not
with running money,

but with the strategy
and people management, organizational management,
and product and distribution.

And it was a tremendously
successful launch of that research practice. I took on a promotion then
to manage our relationships

with 40 CEOs of global buy
side asset management firms. So I had this
incredible window that I

and to go travel
and meet with them. So it was very much luck. And so lucky that I
didn't realize how lucky

I was that I decided to
leave and go to grad school. Went over to
Northwestern, pursued

a master's in marketing with a
focus on data-driven marketing and statistics.

Went to go work at 3M. I thought I was going to work
at 3M in strategy for years. And then the global
financial crisis struck

and they rescinded all their
MBA and master's offers. So I went back to DC,
went back to my old firm,

and then I was
like, gosh, people are going to cut
consulting right now. This is probably not
going to be good.

And started networking
and ended up taking a role at a holding
company that was buying up

defense and intel contractors
with the plan to take it public. And I was like oh,
this sounds like fun.

Go join, be able to be
involved in an IPO roadshow, start to learn about, corporate
development, government

contracting. And that was an
incredible experience. Our first acquisition was John
Brennan's firm, The Analysis

Corporation. And then we started to
acquire some businesses that were doing work with NSA.

But I had the opportunity
then to experience what it was like to be
working at a company that

had gone public and
then we were taken private in a leveraged
buyout by Aries.

And that was a very
operational experience of feeling what that is like,
very different than a growth

equity or a venture investment. And so life then,
with my husband,

ended up taking me to Baltimore. And I said, there's one firm
I'd love to go work for, because the CEO, I
thought, was just

a phenomenal human being,
Bill Stromberg at the time. And ended up going to
work at T. Rowe Price,

and actually worked in
strategy, helping build out their data-driven distribution,
but then was recruited over

to do institutional capital
formation with large sovereign wealths and--

so defined benefit and
defined contribution plans, endowments, foundations,
and starting to structure more
separately managed accounts.

And I loved. I thought I'd be there for life. And then I was recruited over
to this firm, Greenspring Associates, now StepStone.

The founder, had
been in my group at T. Rowe and he said due
diligencing fund managers,

it's the same thing as
raising large-scale capital. It's just two sides of the coin.

You could be a fund investor
and you know more about venture than you think you do. We had a lot of relationships
outside of work in that area,

and my husband was in venture
capital-- early stage venture capital. And so I decided
to take the leap.

Why not? Trust your gut. And I went over there. I was having a
wonderful experience.

Launched their first
Evergreen vehicle, their first emerging
manager fund.

And then the pandemic struck. And people maybe
don't remember this,

but because it seems like
oh, the venture valuations got really high. Everything was up to the right. But for a little while
we thought, oh my gosh,

venture is in the toilet. We're all going to
be looking for jobs. It was a very scary
moment for a little bit.

And we were turning our
attention to focus on China and some other
priorities were shifting.

And I had, kind of, a
principles and values moment. By the way it's
a phenomenal firm and they do really
great things and just

great leader over there. But, I started to have some
conversations with mentors

from different parts of
my life, and it just so happened that they
were starting to get involved in the transition
for the Biden campaign.

And I started to get an itch. And it's funny what happens
when you get an itch. If you get an itch
to do something,

if you ever had that
feeling, it doesn't go away even though you try to quiet it. And then I was fortunate
that my husband said,

yes, you can take a big salary
cut, and I'll support you and you want to do this.

And then I lucked into
getting this amazing letter asking if I would
be willing to serve

leading the Office of
Investment and Innovation. Which, to be honest, Eric,
has felt like the biggest gift

because it integrates
so many different parts of my very nonlinear career.

So I think there's always luck. Anyone who says that they
don't have luck in their career experiences is lying to you.

There's always luck. And then follow your heart so. Well let's talk about
your role and how

those pieces came together. Yes. So tell us about what's within
your office and your mandate.

I'm biased. I think we have the coolest
office at the US Small Business Administration. I agree.

For those that are not
familiar with the SBA, it was established during the
Eisenhower administration,

really with the premise of
public-private partnership at the heart of everything
the agency does in recognition

of the importance
of small businesses in terms of job creation
and economic growth

within the country. And the SBA, believe
it or not, also does everyone know that the
SBA provides more disaster

funding than FEMA. It's an interesting
time right now with what we're going through. The SBA is really critical
with disaster loans.

And the SBA, I'd say, has
been more on everyone's radar with COVID because of the
Paycheck Protection Program, so

a disaster relief
lending program. But in addition to the loan
programs, our office is what I--

it's tough-- the SBA, small
businesses, our office is really about that
innovation economy,

those startup businesses, the
businesses that are scaling. And so our portfolio
focuses there. And one of the gems, there's
a couple gems in the office,

but one of the gems of
the program that we have is the Small Business
Investment Company program, the SBIC program.

You might say, what
in the world is that? Well, it's a $46 billion
pool of assets today

with over 320 private
funds that we manage. So what many respects,
I think of us

very akin to a large
institutional investor that's investing in funds.

However, we're not
a limited partner. We do not put equity
into the fund.

Instead, what we
do is we loan money to the fund as a match
against the private capital.

And as a result of that, we
were a low returning investor

in many ways so
that way more money can go to the limited partners
and the general partners.

And an interesting
thing that happens, when we're talking about it
earlier, when you put leverage on a basket, a diversified
basket of investments,

it can actually serve to de-risk
it while enhancing the return. So it produces more
competitive returns.

And the idea behind the program,
when it was established, was that there was not enough
private capital flowing

to small businesses to help them
start and to help them scale.

And that we needed another way
to incentivize private capital

to come into these areas because
it was so vital to the economy. And so I'll really
stress the point

that it was not the government
replacing our private capital markets, but it
said there is a gap.

And if we add another factor
to the return equation, if we essentially had a
lower returning investor,

that would make
those investments more attractive for the
private sector to put money in.

Because, at the end of the day,
any private investor is saying-- it's a relative value
play about where

you're going to put your money. You're always making
a decision around, do I put it in public equities,
do I put it in venture,

do I put it in growth? You're always making a
decision about return and risk.

And so if we could come up with
a diversified structure that lowers the volatility
and potentially increases

the return, that's
more attractive. And so that's a little
bit about the program. I'll talk more
about it as we go.

It has given rise to
amazing companies. It financed Apple, Amgen,
Whole Foods, Cray Computing.

I mean, the list goes on. Many of the funds in the
program, back in the day, were some of the
original venture capital

funds that financed the
semiconductor industry. Intel was one of
their investments. So the program, probably
never heard of it,

it has played a vital
role in Silicon Valley and many communities
across the country.

But in addition to that, we
have an incredible portfolio called the Small Business
Innovation Research and Tech

Transfer Program, so SBIR, STTR
you may have heard of that, maybe not.

But this program
really cool, created-- gosh, what were we celebrating?

I think the 40th anniversary
of the program recently. The idea that any federal
agency that had a very large R&D

budget that they should set
aside money, specifically for contracts or grants, to
help with R&D, prototyping,

and starting innovative
companies and helping them commercialize. It, is just an amazing program.

We put out $4 billion a
year through this program. And-- so actually, for
any current entrepreneurs

or aspiring entrepreneurs
in the room, this is a phenomenal program. And actually, Stanford is one
of the leading universities

in terms of tech transfer
out of the SBIR program-- or the STTR program. Because with the tech
transfer program,

you have a University coming
in and essentially sponsoring, co-owning some of the
company with an entrepreneur

to drive those ideas forward. So very awesome program we can
provide more information on.

And then some of
the other ecosystem programs you talked about. I'll just touch on The Federal
and State Technology partnership

program, FAST program. The government provides
money every single year to help people navigate how
to apply for the SBIR and STTR

program, which, I think,
is a wonderful thing because federal programs are
not always the easiest thing to navigate.

And as we think
about those numbers, it's absolutely astounding to
think of $4 billion per year

in SBIR funds. When a lot of funds talk about
how much they have assets under management, that's over a
period of time and cumulative,

this is every single year. Four billion every year. We've been four billion for now
the last four years slightly--

but the growth has-- the growth has been steady. So as you think about
it, for better or worse,

as the federal government budget
swells at these large agencies, that means that more money
is put aside for SBIR

and STTR contracts and grants. So if you've heard of
organizations like AFWERX or the Army Applications Lab
or NavalX or many others,

the primary tool that they're
often using is SBIR and STTR.

SBIR and STTR. So linking that with maybe
some more familiar concepts. This is the office
that Bailey leads.

Now here we are. We're in a class called Silicon
Valley and the US government. There are some who say
the private sector doesn't

need government assistance. There are others who
advocate for that. It's an ongoing tension
and yet this program

has persisted, as you
mentioned, for over 40 years. Can you tell us about
the role of this program

and how it affects
our prosperity? So, I'm of the mind
that you often--

you get what you incentivize
and that the government can play a role in helping to
incentivize investments

in certain areas. And I'll give the example-- and by the way, nothing
against software.

I make the joke at home all the
time or my husband makes it. He goes, are you trying
to put me out of business. He's a B2B software investor.

I'm like, no, there's
plenty of private sector money that goes there. It's that we can't
just focus there.

We have to think about
our economic security, our national security.

And we have to think
about how do we make it attractive to invest
in things that are really

long duration in
nature or really, really capital
intensive upfront. How do we make it attractive,
to create factories,

to invest in big 3D printing
machines, hypersonics, biotech,

things where there's
potentially binary outcomes? So I'd offer up that
that is the opportunity,

for the federal government, to
come in and de-risk investment or be able to stimulate
investment in certain areas

by improving the risk
adjusted returns. And SPACs are one way to do it
but the SBIR and STTR programs

de-risk as well by providing
non-dilutive funding to get

early money into
these ideas so you can do the R&D that you need to do.

So you can prototype, so you
can commercialize and then be able to attract more
private capital that

wouldn't come in as early. So SBIR is what I would consider
that earliest of early money

to come in to help get
the business started. And the money that comes
from SBIR all of that

has to specifically go into
the R&D and the prototyping and development work.

Now, there are those who call
this America's Seed Fund. Yes. Can you tell us more
about what that means

and how we could think
about that more accurately? It was a big branding exercise
during the Obama administration,

where they said, OK, well,
rather than call it SBIR, STTR, let's try to think about how
do we capture hearts and minds

and make it clear
to entrepreneurs that we're seeding ideas here.

And to start to increase
awareness of the program more broadly,
rather than thinking

about it as a contracting
or grant mechanism at different agencies.

To make it clear that there is
a large, available pot of money, and it is here to seed
those early ideas.

I think it's been
an excellent thing. It's caught fire. And I think it is a
really elegant way

to describe the
purpose of the program around seeding
those early ideas. Now this is the Small
Business Administration.

Yes. And that definition of small
business is brought up a lot. About what-- who's
included who's not,

especially as, in
Silicon Valley, we are in a world of startups. Yes. Talk us through some
of those definitions

and maybe some of
the ways that-- I'm going to share a lot of
my personal opinions now.

So just as a disclaimer,
these are not opinions of the
Biden-Harris administration.

So innovation economy,
startups and small businesses

have tremendous
differences from, say, your main street businesses
or very asset-light services

businesses. They are-- the commonality
might be that they're all

small from a size
standard perspective, I can talk a little
bit about that,

but they have unique
challenges and different needs. So the SBA sets what
they call size standards

for all small
business government contracting, all small business
programs, small business

lending across the entire
federal government. And so I share this
to say, if you ever

hear somebody say, the
DOD makes it impossible for me to win a contract, I
have to go up against General

Dynamics or Lockheed
Martin, it's actually not the
Department of Defense that's making that
really hard for you.

The Department of Defense has-- they have regulations
that they have to follow

that are set by the SBA. And by the way, these
are regulations, they're not statute.

This is an important thing. So there's no
legislation that actually says it has to be this way
and this is how we define it.

So it is up to the agency. And this is actually a
very interesting time. I won't get into it too much,
but there was a recent Supreme

Court ruling, the
Chevron decision, that reverts back
some of the thinking

and approach around
the discretion and authorities interpretations
of federal agencies in terms

of their statutory authority. So I think it's an
interesting time here because our
regulations, in terms

of what constitutes
a small business, they've been in place for
a very, very long time.

And so why does this matter? So size, it could be
the number of employees, it could be the revenues of the
business and financial services,

it could be the assets
of the business. But there's other elements of
size, control and affiliation.

What in the world do I mean
by control and affiliation? So we'll take control first. So positive and negative
controls of a business.

So you could look at control
based on your ownership. So the percentage of ownership
that you have in a business.

And the negative
controls could be triggered by things like
voting rights of board members.

That's important. And then affiliation,
what's affiliation? So you can be affiliated
with other entities,

other businesses, based
on the level of ownership that they have over you.

Why does this matter? Well, it matters a great deal
within the innovation economy

because, many times, you
need to get outside capital. You're not necessarily always
bootstrapping your business.

And I'd also offer up that
having people on your board can be a good thing
for governance, also

helps with networks. So what's the situation today? Well now it's
fairly restrictive.

It has been, again
my personal opinion, I've had a very
paternalistic view of--

that those regulations take
a very paternalistic view that also favors founder owned
and operated and led businesses.

So individuals that have
bootstrapped their business. If they've bootstrapped
their business

and they meet the
size standards, and they haven't
given up control, they haven't given up
a lot of ownership,

guess what, they often qualify
under different small business set aside programs in
the federal government

to give them a fast path
to government contracting, or to be able to get directed
contracts where they don't even

have to compete. Isn't that amazing? It's incredible. But guess what,
you typically don't

qualify if you have outside,
say, venture capital investment or growth equity
investment because you

trigger these affiliation
and control rules. This is really problematic.

Why is it problematic? Because the commonality
that we have

often with innovative startups
is the fact that they do have the outside investment,
and that is a good thing.

And they have the
outside board members and so they are not eligible
for small business set aside

contracts. And so they have to compete
with really large businesses like General Dynamics
and Lockheed Martin.

Great companies that do a lot of
good for our national security, but they don't have
the same resources.

And so it's often a waste
for them to go head to head with them so what do they do? They end up
subcontracting to them.

So then they don't have a
relationship with the customer directly, and they give
up a lot of their margins, and then, ultimately,
often get acquired

rather than continuing to grow
as independent companies, which can stifle innovation
in many situations.

It also hurts our tax base,
because we polarize the economy with really small
and really large.

So during the pandemic, an
interesting thing happened. Some folks might remember this,
that, all of a sudden, most

of these venture
backed businesses, they couldn't get a PPP loan. Oh my gosh, they could
not get a PPP loan.

So we were about to lose all
of these amazing businesses with great IP, doing
innovative things because

of these affiliation
and control rules, because SBA lending follows
these rules as well.

The NVCA was very
vocal about this. And the agency moved and waved
the affiliation and control

rules to get loans out. Then during this administration,
I had a nice opportunity,

actually, to be in charge
of our loan programs and our investment programs
for a period of time. And we push forward changes in
our regulations for lending,

where now the affiliation and
control rules do not apply in all of our lending programs.

Which is amazing because now-- and particularly following SVB
weekend and less venture debt,

more venture-backed
businesses can get access to low cost government loans
for working capital, and also

asset-based lending programs. But we haven't addressed
the contracting problem. And it is a large
problem, I would say.

And there are potential
solutions to fix it. And I would say it
is vital when it

comes to innovative startups,
particularly those that are very capital-intensive.

And the last point
I'll share-- sorry, I could go on with
this about a long time, is that the interesting
thing about the nature

of these regulations
and the paternalism is that we have had
these programs that

are focused on helping
have government contracting pathways for socially
and economically

disadvantaged businesses. But the irony is, I go
back to my earlier point, that those pathways
exist for individuals

that have enough
money to bootstrap and self-fund their businesses.

So isn't that a
little bit backwards, because it typically isn't the
person that has enough money

to bootstrap their business
that is going and getting venture funding,
they're often going

to get outside funding because
they don't have the money. And we are in effect--

we have set conditions such that
the very entrepreneurs that need

the money the most, cannot take
that money and pursue government

contracts as a small business
so I'd say it seems a little backwards today.

So, Bailey, let's talk about
one more topic before we go over to Q&A. You've been
leading the Small Business

Investment company program. You mentioned the size
of it, over 46 billion. 46 billion now.

I know. It's insane. And funding out there right now. It's a program that's
been around since 1958.

And under your
leadership, it's been

really amazing to
see what you've been able to do to work more
with the venture community. You introduced a
new tool called--

or a new financial instrument
called the accrual to venture. And you've also worked
on a partnership

with the Department of Defense
and the Office of Strategic capital. Can you tell us a little
more about that program

and give us an update
on how it's going? Yeah. So I'll start with when I
had the fortunate opportunity

to move into this position,
one of the first things that I did was sit
down with my team.

Many folks in the team had been
there for 20 some odd years and I said, what's on
your wish list of things

that we accomplish over
the next couple of years. And also what are our
principles and values?

I enjoyed talking with
you about your work, but what are our
principles and values

and also how do those tie to the
mission and intent of Congress with the programs that we are
responsible for administering?

Because at the end of the
day, we're here to serve and our job is to deliver
on that mission and intent.

And the mission and intent of
Congress with the SBC program was to stimulate and supplement
the flow of equity capital

with the ability to provide
private debt and long-term loans to small businesses and
startups to enhance job

creation and economic growth. And then it goes
on to talk about-- a focus on things that are
manufactured and produced

domestically as well. So I think that a lot of supply
chain that goes on later about national security.

And we all agreed that
we'd give ourselves a low mark in terms of how we're
doing on meeting the mission

and intent of Congress, because
the program, for the last 20 years, had been
providing funding to a lot of mezzanine debt
funds and direct lending funds

and structured equity
and some buyout. But we asked ourselves why?

We said, why is this happening? And it was happening
because one,

we had poor product/market
fit with our loan instrument. Think of it like, an
agency-backed security.

Poor product/market
fit for anything that was doing equity
investing in long term loans. That was one.

And then the
regulations were all written around that instrument
and around the types

of teams that were providing
mezzanine debt funding. And regulations have been
written over time that just--

people add to regulation. Often they don't
maybe look at it and design thinking, say,
like what to take away.

And so we sat down as a team,
and we started to pick it apart and said like, what
are-- let's try

to agree on individual points. And what needs to change
in regulation, what do

we need to change procedurally? And came together and
agreed on a set of things

that we'd like to see evolve. And then asked different
individuals across the team

to write. Say you rewrite it, you change
parts of the regulation, and let's come together
and review it collectively

as a team. And so one of the things
I'm thrilled about is that we took a team approach.

Had very much aligned
on what our mission was and the principles and what
our goals and objectives were.

And with that, we
were able to advance the creation of a new government
guaranteed loan designed

to have good product/market
fit with early stage VC funds, growth equity
funds, fund of funds.

What I call buy and
build strategies where it might be
control equity. And the demand and interest
has been phenomenal.

We had 127 applications
for our program this year, typically we had about
33 in a given year.

So it's just been absolutely
tremendous growth. And it is phenomenal to see
just the enthusiasm and also

the bipartisan support for the
program at this point in time. And then the other part
is a little bit of luck

that Jason Ritchie, who's
the director of OSC, was doing some consulting for
the National Economic Council

and the National Security
Council at the time that I was on a White House
interagency policy committee

on scale manufacturing. And I really felt it
was important to get buy in on this new instrument
and regulatory changes

from the White House and
a broader base of agencies

before bringing it forward. And Jason said, oh my
gosh, if you do this,

could we talk about
a partnership. Because this instrument,
he had conviction,

would help start to show a
pathway of how we could solve

for some of the challenges
around investment in technologies critical
to national security.

And again, luck and
also personalities. Jason's a no ego person.

We had all of our
teams involved. We gained a lot of momentum
for bringing this forward.

And the White House
liked the idea that the Defense
Department was pairing up with an agency that had been
doing this for a long time.

And that gave birth to the
Office of Strategic Capital, our very first program,
which we call the SBAC

critical technologies
initiative. Where now the federal
government is providing government-guaranteed
loans to funds

that are investing in critical
tech areas at the early stage, at scale up, but also on
the debt side as well.

So we're trying to address
the entire capital stack. I am very pleased to
say that next week we'll

be making some big
announcements about another-- a very good diversified
group of funds that

will be the first to
invest in this area. And a strong base
of limited partners that are investing in them
because they've done the math

and they see this is a good
thing for the private sector too. And Bailey, one
more thing before we

go to Q&A. If you could unpack
just a little bit about what this new critical
technologies initiative can

unlock in terms of
the technology areas that you can address. Yes. So there's 14 critical
technology areas.

I recommend going to the DOD
research and an engineering website to look at
all the critical tech,

but I'll give you an
idea of some of the areas that these funds are focused on.

And by the way, the funds
are not focused on one area and this is an important thing. So it was important that these
funds have large TAMs, Total

Addressable Markets,
and that they be able to diversify across
technologies and industries

to make sure that they're in a
position to diversify away risk while having the opportunity
for outperformance.

But it's things
like hypersonics, and trusted AI, and biotech, and
renewable energy, cybersecurity,

space, these are big
topics and big areas. But I'd say what is incredibly
encouraging, oh yeah,

advanced manufacturing, we
have a lot going on there. That it is, a broad
base of different areas,

but it's areas that
have been identified because there is not enough
capital flowing to these areas.

And the investments are
often long-duration in nature or require a lot of
